awd_titl_txt: Exploring the Solar Neighborhood with the GALEX All Sky Survey
awd_abstract_narration:
The history of element creation in our Milky Way galaxy is preserved in dwarf stars.   By observing the nearby stars at ultraviolet (UV) wavelengths the investigators will unravel that history. The investigators will use the GALEX satellite images to measure the properties of the relatively faint dwarf stars in the solar neighborhood.   These observations, made at UV wavelengths, complement observations made at the optical and infrared wavelengths with ground based telescopes.  The investigators will also advance our knowledge of nearby stars, with potential impacts across other fields of astronomy.  

The research activity is designed to help train a young scientist and the project is defined as a set of projects suitable for high school students. The investigator's team will bring underrepresented minorities into their research, expanding participation in basic science.

The investigators will measure the UV-based colors of stars and calibrate the colors to estimate stellar metallicity and stellar age. Their research will aid in understanding the formation and age of stars in our galaxy.  They will combine measurements of dwarf star colors from previous optical surveys, such as the Sloan Digital Sky Survey and the Geneva-Copenhagen Survey, to determine the age-metallicity relations and age-versus-trajectory for stars in the Milky Way.

por.por_cntn:
Main sequence F and G stars in the solar neighborhood carry with them relic information about the Galactic disk from which they formed. Their properties that hold such fossil information are their chemical abundances, their motions within the Galaxy, and their age. Of these the hardest to measure is age. This project has developed one technique for age dating such stars that is based upon their far-ultraviolet (FUV) magnitudes as measured by the GALEX  orbiting observatory. The new technique has been applied to a sample of several hundred stars to define the age versus velocity dispersion relation in the solar neighborhood. This relation depends upon the processes that defined the initial orbits, and then modified them over time by dynamical heating mechanisms acting within the Galactic disk.

A calibration sample of late-F, G, and early-K field dwarf stars was compiled from the literature for which ages had been formerly derived largely by measurements of chromospheric or coronal stellar activity. For this sample, FUV magnitudes from GALEX have been combined with both Johnson BV photometry and three-color photometry from the Gaia space-based observatory. From these data were constructed two-color diagrams of both (FUV-B) versus (B-V), and (FUV-BP) versus (BP-G). The stars are distributed within these diagrams in such a way as to exhibit considerable FUV brightness at a given optical color. Upper envelopes, denoted here as f_(B-V) and f_(BP-G), were fitted to the two-color data as functions of B-V and (BP-G) respectively, and two FUV-excess indices Q = (FUV-B)-f_(B-V) and Q = (FUV-BP)-f_(BP-G) were derived.

The GALEX FUV bandpass for F, G, and K stars encompasses emission lines and continuum light from a stellar chromosphere and transition region, the strength of which were known a priori to correlate with the age of FGK dwarf stars. Thus, a basic hypothesis of the proposal was that the two FUV-excess indices of such stars would correlate with stellar activity and thereby age. This was demonstrated in several studies, and a key finding of this award was that the Q parameters could be mathematically fitted as a function of the age of the calibration stars. A main product of the award was thereby to derive fitted equations into which values of Q and (B-V), or Q and (BP-G), could be input and the age of a late-F, G, or early-K dwarf star calculated. This work adds one new method to a limited number of techniques that astronomers have available with which to derive or estimate the ages of main sequence stars of mass similar to the Sun in the general (non-cluster) field of the Galactic disk.

A match was sought between the GALEX GR6/7 data release and stars in the Geneva Copenhagen Survey (GCS). This activity produced a compilation of F and G dwarfs in the solar neighborhood for which ages were derived from FUV photometry, and for which there was also data on the metallicity and three components of the space velocity within the Milky Way galaxy. The stars were binned according to FUV-age and trends sought with both metallicity and velocity dispersion. No correlation was found between stellar age and metallicity. The velocity dispersion, sigma, was found to vary with stellar age t as a power-law, with sigma being proportional to t^{0.24}. Such an observed trend is consistent with Galactic models in which stars are scattered by gravitational interactions with giant molecular clouds (GMCs). The older a star, the more likely is lt to have had multiple encounters with GMCs, which perturbed the orbit of the star within the Galactic disk. 

The basic outcome of the GALEX-GCS project, therefore, was that the observed age-velocity relations derived from the Q-based FUV-ages are similar to those predicted by theoretical models in which the orbits of stars within the Galactic disk are modified by the scattering of stars from encounters with giant molecular clouds. This, and other dynamical ``heating'' mechanisms, lead to migration of the orbits of old stars within the Galactic disk. Stars currently within the solar vicinity can thus have formed at very different distances from the Galactic Center, and are only briefly passing through the current neighborhood of the Sun. One consequence of this circumstance is that the solar neighborhood is constituted of a very heterogeneous ensemble of stars with different ages and places of formation within the Galactic disk. This factor has to be allowed for when interpreting the age-metallicity relation, or lack thereof, among stars currently in the solar neighborhood.

A study of GALEX photometry of stars in several open clusters has drawn attention to one possible limitation of the FUV-age-dating technique for dwarf stars. Stellar activity cycles, analogous to the solar sunspot cycle, could introduce short-timescale scatter into a long-term FUV emission versus stellar age relation.
